repnme.cdata!:
Lao People's Democratic Republic -
            First, Second, and Third Poverty Education Support
            Operations Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Poverty Education Support Operations Project for Lao
            People's Democratic Republic (PDR) were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: take into account the small size of the
            Lao PDR program and opportunity costs of the World Bank (WB)
            team in pursuing an overambitious budget support operation.
            In addition, every action or trigger should be accompanied
            with technical assistance (TA) or other WB program in order
            to achieve outcomes. The reform areas to which the
            Government has not fully committed or that do not have
            enough capacity or champions in the Government that are able
            to lead reforms should not be included, while the dialog in
            these areas should continue through other instruments, such
            as analytical and advisory services (AAAs) and capacity
            building activities. The emphasis should be shifted from
            actions and triggers to outcomes and indicators, leading to
            a more streamlined policy matrix of maximum 6 triggers and
            12 actions. Relying on outcomes will also allow focusing on
            achieving outcomes through a coherent and well-timed
            program, rather than focusing on having an action in each
            sub-sector every year. Triggers and actions should be worded
            more flexibly and indicatively, to allow for adjustments
            along the way that would lead to better outcomes rather than
            fulfilling the matrix to the letter. The Government should
            also get credit for reforms that lead to the outcomes, even
            if these were not initially envisioned in the matrix.

repnme.cdata!:
Lao - First Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit and Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This First Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit and Grant Project, jointly prepared with the
            Government and in collaboration with other donors, provides
            an overarching framework for a programmatic three-year
            policy reform Program, and, performance indicators in line
            with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS). The Project aims
            at ensuring that public resources are both available, and
            effectively used to meet Lao PDR's development
            outcomes. Three broad benefits can be identified: improved
            public expenditure management performance; alignment of
            public expenditures with pro-poor National Growth and
            Poverty eradication Strategy (NGPES) goals; and, enhanced
            environment for growth and revenue generation. While the
            project also entails benefits such as policy prioritization
            and donor coordination, predictability of funding and donor
            support, and, budget support within macro stability, five
            main risks could affect the impact of the proposed
            operation: the authorities' uneven commitment to
            reforms; a weak public financial management system leads to
            a high fiduciary risk; provincial autonomy hinders
            implementation of national Policies, and an equitable
            distribution of resources; short-term fiscal
            un-sustainability; and, severe capacity constraints in the
            civil service. The project benefits outweigh its risks, and
            furthermore, an explicit recognition by the Government of
            weaknesses, will place Capacity Enhancement (CE) at the
            center of the reform program. As a result, capacity is being
            strengthened through reforms, and by the active engagement
            of other donors.
